person_203.name: Jean-BaptisteBiot
person_203.description: French mathematician, physicist and astronomer; Professor of Physics at the Collège de France. ForMemRSL.

person_520.name: Jean-AndréDeluc
person_520.description: Swiss-born geologist, natural philosopher and meteorologist who spent much of his time working in England. FRSL.

person_331.name: Christoph HeinrichPfaff
person_331.description: German physician, chemist and physicist who worked on animal electricity alongside Volta and Humboldt. The younger brother of mathematician Johann Friedrich Pfaff.

person_317.name: PaulErman
person_317.description: German physician and physicist. He was mainly interested in electricity and magnetism and was the first recipient of the Volta Prize. ForMemRSL.

person_383.name: WilliamGilbert
person_383.description: English physician, man of science, and author of the influential treatise De Magnete (1600).

person_124.name: FrancisBacon
person_124.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

person_085.name: Plato
person_085.description: A pupil of Socrates, much of Plato's large corpus of surviving philosophical texts are written in the form of Socratic dialogues. He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

person_138.name: Aristotle
person_138.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

person_103.name: RobertBoyle
person_103.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

person_246.name: RobertHooke
person_246.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

person_390.name: Otto deGuericke
person_390.description: German man of science, politican and inventor, who invented the first air pump and showed the power of a vacuum.

person_032.name: FrancisHauksbee
person_032.description: English natural philosopher best known for his work on electricity and electrostatic repulsion. FRSL

person_036.name: IsaacNewton
person_036.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

person_392.name: StephenGray
person_392.description: English chemist, who worked on electricity. FRSL.

person_393.name: Charles Francois de Cisternay duFay
person_393.description: French chemist and superintedent of the Jardin du Roi, who worked on electricity. ForMemRSL.

person_543.name: Ewald Georg vonKleist
person_543.description: German speaking lawyer and natural philosopher who invented a form of the Leyden jar.

person_704.name: AndreasCunaeus
person_704.description: Dutch lawyer who experimented with the Leyden Jar.

person_542.name: Pieter vanMusschenbroek
person_542.description: Dutch natural philosopher who invented the Leyden Jar. ForMemRSL.

person_524.name: Rene-AntoineRéaumur
person_524.description: French entomologist who developed a widely used temperature scale. ForMemRSL.

person_541.name: WilliamWatson
person_541.description: Natural philosopher who worked on electrostatics. FRSL.

person_394.name: BenjaminFranklin
person_394.description: Man of science born in Philadelphia. Inventor, printer, publisher, political philosopher, and a Founding Father of the United States. FRSL.

person_539.name: PeterCollinson
person_539.description: Cloth merchant, gardener and botanist and part of a trans-Atlantic correspondence network. FRSL.

person_462.name: Franz Ulrich TheodorAepinus
person_462.description: German born natural philosopher who mostly worked in Russia. Best known for his researches, theoretical and experimental, in electricity and magnetism.

person_026.name: HenryCavendish
person_026.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_537.name: WilliamStukeley
person_537.description: Anglican clergyman, physician, significant antiquary natural philosopher and a friend of Newton's. FRSL.

person_538.name: Jean-AntioneNollet
person_538.description: French clergyman and natural philosopher specialising in electrostatics. ForMemRSL.

person_480.name: Giovanni BattistaBeccaria
person_480.description: Italian physicist, particularly the study of electricity. ForMemRSL

person_086.name: JohnCanton
person_086.description: An experimental natural philosopher and teacher, especially in the field of electricity. FRSL.

person_049.name: Louis BernardGuyton de Morveau
person_049.description: French chemist and revolutionary politician who is credited with producing the first systematic method of chemical nomenclature. ForMemRSL.

person_535.name: Franz KarlAchard
person_535.description: Prussian chemist who found how to extract sugar from beet.

person_269.name: LuigiGalvani
person_269.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

person_380.name: AbrahamBennet
person_380.description: Natural philosopher and close associate with Priestley, Darwin and Wedgwood. He recorded atmospheric electricity. FRSL.

person_199.name: AlessandroVolta
person_199.description: Professor of experimental physics at the University of Pavia. At the end of the eighteenth century he Invented the Voltaic pile which produced electric current and which Davy shortly dubbed the battery. Davy described meeting him in 1814 in notebook 14/I, p.38. ForMemRSL.

person_544.name: ImmanuelKant
person_544.description: Professor of Logic and Metaphysics at the University of Königsberg. Regarded as the most important philosopher of the eighteenth century.

person_078.name: JohnLocke
person_078.description: English philosopher and physician, widely regarded as one of the most influential of early Enlightenment thinkers. FRSL.

person_018.name: DavidHartley
person_018.description: Associationist, whose work argued that the vibrations of nerves created sensation. FRSL.

person_545.name: Martin vanMarum
person_545.description: Dutch physician, natural philosopher, and inventor; Director of the Dutch Society of Sciences. ForMemRSL.

person_498.name: JohnCuthbertson
person_498.description: English-born scientific instrument maker who spent much of his career in the Netherlands. Working with Van Marum, he developed glass-plated frictional electrical machines.

person_517.name: WilhelmHisinger
person_517.description: Swedish physicist and chemist who collaborated with Jöns Jacob Berzelius.

person_349.name: Jöns JacobBerzelius
person_349.description: Swedish chemist. He discovered the chemical elements cerium and selenium, and was the first to isolate silicon, thorium, titanium, and zirconium. A rival of Davy's whom he met a few times.

person_050.name: Louis NicolasVauquelin
person_050.description: French pharmacist and chemist who met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

person_201.name: Louis JacquesThénard
person_201.description: Held chairs of chemistry at the Collège de France and the Ecole Polytechnique. Worked closely with Gay-Lussac and met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

person_012.name: Joseph LouisGay-Lussac
person_012.description: French chemist and physicist, known mostly for his discovery that water is made of two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen by volume (with Alexander von Humboldt), for two laws related to gases, and for his work on alcohol-water mixtures. Became involved in controversies with Davy over various chemical discoveries. ForMemRSL.

person_471.name: WilliamHarvey
person_471.description: Physician who discovered the circulation of the blood.

place_1073.name: Philadelphia
place_1073.description: the most populous city in the U.S. state of Pennsylvania

otherwork_181.author: William Stukeley

otherwork_163.author: Joseph Priestley
